DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China said workers outside of Hubei and Beijing are no longer needed to be subject to quarantine rules, if certain conditions are met. (Newswires)

Italian coronavirus confirmed cases rose to 3089 (prev. 2502) and deaths rose to 107 (prev. 79) according to an official. Furthermore, Italian Government is to close schools and universities until mid-March, while it is also planning to ban public events, close cinemas and theatres across the country due to the virus. (Newswires)

New York Governor Cuomo said total confirmed cases in New York rose to 11 (Prev. 6). Furthermore, total cases in greater Seattle rose to 39 (Prev. 27) and deaths increased to 10 (Prev. 9), while California reported its first death from coronavirus. (Newswires)

Coronavirus cases in UK increased by 34 to a total of 85, while France has reported 45 new coronavirus cases to bring the total to 257. (Newswires/BBC)

IMF MD Georgieva said IMF is to launch a USD 50bln aid package for the coronavirus and China is aiming to get 90% production by month-end. (Newswires)

US House passed USD 8.3bln coronavirus bill as expected, which followed reports that congressional negotiators agreed to a USD 8.3bln coronavirus emergency bill with USD 3bln designated for R&D of vaccines, therapies and diagnostics. (Newswires) 

 

ASIA-PAC

RBA's Debelle said we have the capacity to cut once more and after that will have to consider QE, while he does not think that negative rates are something that should be contemplated and noted that drought is having a "very noticeable" impact on the Australian economy. Debelle also noted the bushfires did not have much of an impact on Q4 2020 GDP but will have a larger impact in Q1 2020. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

BoE Incoming Governor Bailey said BoE can take the bank rate down to about 0.1%, while he added policy ammunition is "uncomfortably close" to average rate cut needed in a cycle and that the BoE does not have a lot of room for policy manoeuvre. Bailey also noted that long-term rates are predominantly structural, reflecting ageing and weak productivity and that they need to think of rebalancing to give fiscal policy more of a role. (Newswires)

BoE's Broadbent said there could be a role for economic policy to support activity and credit provision amid the COVID-19 outbreak, while we are in regular and close contact with government officials and other central banks. (Newswires)

UK Environment Minister Eustice said he is optimistic the UK can strike a deal on fishing with the EU by July. (Newswires)

  • UK Composite PMI Final (Feb) 53.0 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3)
  • EU Markit Services Final PMI (Feb) 52.6 vs. Exp. 52.8 (Prev. 52.8)

  • EU Retail Sales (Jan) Y/Y 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.3%, Rev. 1.7%)
  • German Markit Services PMI (Feb) 52.5 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3)
  • German Markit Composite Final PMI (Feb) 50.7 vs. Exp. 51.1 (Prev. 51.1)

 

FX

Canadian BoC Rate Decision N/A 1.25% vs. Exp. 1.75% (Prev. 1.75%). Governing Council stands ready to adjust monetary policy further if required and stated that while Canada’s economy has been operating close to potential with inflation at target, the virus is a material negative shock to the Canadian and global outlooks. BoC suggested the outlook is clearly weaker now than it was in January and it will continue to ensure that the Canadian financial system has sufficient liquidity. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES 

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 0.785M vs. Exp. 2.644M (Prev. 0.452M). (Newswires)

OPEC+ Ministerial Panel ended with no agreements as Russia was still reluctant for deeper production cuts according to a source, while it was earlier reported that OPEC+ JMMC was reportedly discussing an option of a 1.5mln BPD production cut. (Newswires)

Iranian Oil Minister said no final deal has yet been made on reaching a deal with non-OPEC producers, while UAE Energy Minister said OPEC+ JMMC made a recommendation although did not reveal it but said Russia is onboard, according to S&P Global Platts. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

US 

Fed Beige Book stated that the US Economic activity expanded at a modest to moderate rate over past several weeks with COVID-19 being cited as a risk which was already weighing on travel and tourism. Manufacturing activity expanded in most of the US although some supply chain delays due to the virus were reported and producers feared further disruption, while consumer spending generally picked up although growth was uneven across the US. Furthermore, most near-term outlooks were for modest growth with the virus and the Presidential election cited as a risk. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dovish) said rates are in the right place for now, while he noted that risks are rising that COVID-19 could be more severe and that the Fed has taken out some insurance. (Newswires)

Fed adopted final rule establishing stress capital buffer for large US banks which Fed staff estimate would increase capital requirement for largest banks and lower requirements for smaller, less complex banks. (Newswires)

  • US ADP National Employment (Feb) 183k vs. Exp. 170.0k (Prev. 291.0k, Rev. 209k). (Newswires)
  • US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 57.3 vs. Exp. 54.9 (Prev. 55.5)
  • US Markit Services PMI Final (Feb) 49.4 (Prev. 49.4)
  • US Markit Composite Final PMI (Feb) 49.6 (Prev. 49.6)

 

MARKET RECAP

Equities pared their losses on Wednesday, led by the Healthcare sector, amid Biden beating Sanders in Super Tuesday, thus lowering equity risk premium of a socialist government. Additionally, there could be some "mean reversion" at play following the losses recorded on Tuesday post the Fed's emergency rate cut. Note that the BoC joined the Fed with a 50bps cut on Wednesday. The TPLEX saw steepening as sentiment improved and STIR traders react to central bank rate cuts, while "catch up" corporate issuance weighed on the long end of the curve. The steeper curve, alongside a renewed risk appetite, helped the greenback pare recent losses. The risk moves were also supported by strong ADP and ISM Non-Manufacturing. Health care (XLV), particularly insurers (UNH, CI, ANTM, CNC, HUM), outperformed today with the sector up over 5% heading into the tail end of the session as Biden staged a turnaround on Super Tuesday securing 10 state victories out of the 14 Super Tuesday primaries, resulting in a blow to Sanders who is an advocate for Medicare for all. Uber (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) benefitted after the former’s CEO stated the co. is in a better position now to achieve profitability on an EBITDA basis in Q420 than it was on the initial announcement, while also adding its Eats business is benefitting from the coronavirus. United Airlines (UAL) announced it is reducing flights and freezing hiring amid COVID-19; trimming international flying by 20% and US flying by 10% for April, with similar reductions expected for May. Skyworks (SWKS) cut its Q2 guidance due to the coronavirus impacting demand; noting the virus has not disrupted manufacturing operations to date. General Electric (GE) reaffirmed FY20 guidance, although noted FCF from its manufacturing operations in Q1 will be hit between USD 300-500mln, and an impact on negative operating profit of USD 200-300mln Impact of COVID-19 is not included in outlook beyond Q1 but it is incorporated in its FY guidance. SPX +4.2% at 3130, NDX +4.1% at 8949, DJ +4.9% at 27,090.

The Treasury curve bull steepened pronouncedly as the front-end rallied amid global monetary policy easing – BoC being the latest G7 to cut rates. Desks noted a slew of real money/CTAs engaging in steepeners on Wednesday, finding some momentum on the back of a strong ADP employment report (183k vs. exp. 170k) and ISM Non-Mfg. (57.3 vs. exp. 54.9), in addition to a pickup in appetite for equities. Meanwhile, as more corporate IG issuers return to the dollar market, the belly- to long-end was under additional pressure as issuance played catch up following the two-week dry spell. Although one desk noted a particular asset manager who was keeping a lid on the steepening, selling a total of 34,452 TUs (2s) while buying 11,175 TNs (10s). The overhanging virus and potential QE is likely providing some support further out the curve. By settlement, 10-year yield had risen back to 1.00%, whilst the whole curve had steepened with the 2-year yield down 8bps and the 30-year yield unchanged on the day. US T-note futures (H0) settled 8 ticks higher at 136-08.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 4th March 2020: Markets pare losses; Biden beats Sanders; BOC cuts 50bps
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Joe Biden storms ahead of Sanders on Super Tuesday; BoC cuts 50bps; ADP and ISM Non-Mfg. firm, yet to be virus-affected; jitters ahead of OPEC+ meeting.
  • COMING UP: Events and Speakers: OPEC meeting. Fed’s Williams and Kaplan, BoE’s Carney and Haldane, BoC’s Poloz. EU’s Barnier after UK trade talks. Data: US Challenger layoffs, Initial Jobless Claims, Factory orders, Durable Goods revisions. Earnings: KR & COST.

* MARKET WRAP: Equities pared their losses on Wednesday, led by the Healthcare sector, amid Biden beating Sanders in Super Tuesday, thus lowering equity risk premium of a socialist government. Additionally, there could be some "mean reversion" at play following the losses recorded on Tuesday post the Fed's emergency rate cut. Note that the BoC joined the Fed with a 50bps cut on Wednesday. The TPLEX saw steepening as sentiment improved and STIR traders react to central bank rate cuts, while "catch up" corporate issuance weighed on the long end of the curve. The steeper curve, alongside a renewed risk appetite, helped the greenback pare recent losses. The risk moves were also supported by strong ADP and ISM Non-Manufacturing, although desks look past the figures due to expectations of them soon falling victim to COVID-19 - which continues to see a rising number of cases and deaths in Western nations now. Meanwhile, crude did not enjoy the rally as jitters grew on Russia's commitment for further production cuts ahead of the OPEC+ meeting on Thursday and Friday.

* BOC: The Bank of Canada cut by 50bps, taking its benchmark rate to 1.25%. Money markets had priced around 40bps worth of easing, so the move was in line with market-derived expectations. The BOC also maintained its easing bias, stating that it stood ready to adjust monetary policy further if required, while it dropped the reference in its January statement which stated policy was at an appropriate level. The In its policy statement, the Bank said that while the economy had been operating close to potential, with inflation at target, the virus is a “material” negative shock (borrowing from other G7 central banker language) to the Canadian and global outlooks; business activity in some regions has fallen sharply and supply chains have been disrupted, reflective in CAD and commodities, the statement noted. The BOC also believes that as the virus spreads, business and consumer confidence will deteriorate further, which will depress activity. In light of all these developments, the central bank said that the outlook was clearly weaker now than it was in January.

* SUPER TUESDAY: Joe Biden came out supreme from the Super Tuesday Democratic primary race, standing - at time of writing - with 365 delegates won (leaving total at 418), in a blow to Bernie Sanders who won 303 delegates (total at 363). Biden won Alabama, Arkansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia & Maine. Meanwhile, Sanders won Colorado, Utah and Vermont, although also looks set to win California. The outperformance of Biden on Super Tuesday puts him in a strong position to secure the nominee, barring a major upset, and immediately subsided market fears of a Medicare for all policy pushed by Sanders (reflective in healthcare stock outperformance on Wednesday). As participants now largely expect a Biden vs. Trump 2020 election battle, the question for investors becomes one of who is the most "market-friendly", which desks have divided opinions on, although more generally see it as markedly closer call than the Trump vs. the pro-socialist Sanders. Additionally, there had been a consensus that Trump would have an "easy" time regaining office against Sanders, while the more moderate Biden would be more likely to gain wider votes, thus leading to a tighter race, giving investors more reason to entertain Biden's proposed policies. Looking ahead, the next primaries take place on March 10th, where states voting include Idaho (20), Michigan (125), Mississippi (36), Missouri (68), North Dakota (14), Washington (89).

* ADP PAYROLLS: ADP reported 183k payrolls was added to the US economy in February, topping the consensus 170k; the prior month's print was downwardly revised, to 209k from 291k (some analysts explained that the large downward revision was due to back-fitting past ADP data to the official BLS series, and not to over-read into it regarding the strength of the labour market). ADP said that the labor market remains firm, and that job creation remained heavily concentrated in large companies, which continue to be the strongest performer. However, Moody's economist Zandi noted in the report that it did not show any impact from the coronavirus: "COVID-19 will need to break through the job market firewall if it is to do significant damage to the economy. The firewall has some cracks, but judging by the February employment gain, it should be strong enough to weather most scenarios." Zandi also noted that decent weather conditions helped the data.

* ISM NON-MANUFACTURING ISM (FEB): Rose to 57.3 from 55.5, beating the expected 54.9, and outside of the highest forecast; Business Activity rose fell to 57.8 from 60.9, below the expected 58.8, however. New Orders rose to 63.1 from 56.2, Employment rose to 55.6 from 53.1, and Price Paid fell to 50.8 from 55.5. On the surface the release shows a clear pick up in services, with the forward-looking components painting a rosier picture too. However, Oxford Economics notes the unfortunate timing of the survey, where the coronavirus has not yet delivered shocks to supply and demand (as looks like increasingly will be the case), and as of such, expects the index to take a tumble in next month.

* COVID-19 UPDATE: Cases continued to rise on Wednesday in Western economies as states warn and prepare for epidemics. Wednesday's official CDC report showed a rise of 3 deaths to a total of 9 in the US, with total cases standing at 80, although since then there have been reports of two more deaths, including California's first. The UK reported a relatively large 34 case increase, bringing the total figure to 85. In Italy, the government has now suspended schools and universities till mid-March, in addition to cutting public events such as concerts and theatre. In the US, congressional representatives agreed to an USD 8.3bln virus emergency bill; USD 3bln designated for R&D of vaccines, therapies and diagnostic. Furthermore, IMF MD Georgieva said the IMF is to launch a USD 50bln aid package. In China, however, production seems to be edging back to normal, where companies have continued to announce more production increases, albeit tentative, including Apple (AAPL) which has reopened 38 of its 48 stores.

* WTI (J0) SETTLES USD 0.40 LOWER AT USD 46.78/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLES USD 0.73 LOWER AT USD 51.13/BBL: Energy markets reversed earlier gains on Wednesday as jitters grew on the eve of OPEC+ that Russia would not provide its support. In the earlier session, sources reports, that members were pushing for production cuts in excess of 600k BPD and even more than 1mln BPD, in addition to wider risk appetite, kept positive momentum in the crude complex. However, the OPEC optimism faced headwinds on WSJ sources reporting that Russia had been opposed to a Saudi-proposed 1.2mln BPD additional cut. Note that earlier Iranian oil minister had said that he believes Russia would resist the cuts until the last moment, something that the market generally considers Russia’s de facto strategy to OPEC meetings. The JMMC technical committee, which concluded there meeting on Wednesday, reportedly did not reach an agreement due to Russia’s reluctance for additional cuts, according to a source, which suggested Russia wants an extension of the existing cuts to the end of Q2 while other members want between 1mln-1.5mln. However, the UAE Energy Minister later said, as cited by S&P Global Platts, that the technical committee made a recommendation that Russia is onboard with, although would not provide further details. Meanwhile across the Atlantic, the latest EIA US inventory data was largely ignored, it was a bullish report however, where crude stocks built less than expected, including a chunky draw at Cushing, and both the products reported larger than expected draws, although production did rise to 13.1mln BPD with a larger decline than expected in refinery utilisation. Elsewhere, Goldman Sachs lowered its oil price forecasts in which it sees Brent to trough in April at USD 45/bbl then recover to USD 60/bbl vs. prev. forecast of decline to USD 53/bbl then recovery to USD 65/bbl.

* FED: Fed's Evans (non-voter, dove) said that he thought the Fed was well positioned but felt the rate cut would help boost confidence given rising risks and potential economic weakening – is comfortable with current policy position. Evans expects the coronavirus will have a short-lived imprint on US, with a quarter or half-year of slowing growth and a V-shaped rebound. The Chicago Fed President went on to say the possibility of hitting zero rates again means the Fed should use its ammunition. Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dove) spoke, saying rates are in the right place for now - Fed has taken out some insurance - but risks are rising that the virus could be more severe. Looking towards the March FOMC meeting post the emergency cut, Bullard said the situation is very fluid, not to prejudge and put a lot of weight on the meeting; although, said he sees downside risks and stands ready to adjust policy, with all tools on the table. On the emergency cut, Bullard said that the rationale was that if the Fed were to cut at the March meeting, it may as well cut now. However, Bullard did note that the economy at the moment is doing quite good and that the rate cuts could encourage investments that might not normally be made.

* FED BEIGE BOOK: US Economic activity expanded at a modest to moderate rate over past several weeks with COVID-19 being cited as a risk, as well as already weighing on travel and tourism. Manufacturing activity expanded in most of the US although some supply chain delays were due to the virus and producers feared further disruption. Consumer spending generally picked up although growth was uneven across the US. Most near-term outlooks were for modest growth with the virus and the Presidential election cited as a risk. Employment increased at a slight to moderate pace, constrained by tight labour market; manufacturers, retailers and transportation firms had lower demand in some districts. Wages rose at a modest to moderate pace, pressured higher by the tight labour market and raise in minimum wage. Some firms were optimistic the Phase One trade deal would cut prices of goods, although some still struggled with tariffs and feared further of COVID-19's effects on prices. Although this beige book could be deemed as stale following the Fed’s emergency 50bps rate cut yesterday, it was the first to incorporate how the coronavirus has been affecting different parts of the economy, up until February 24th.

* BOE: Money markets are currently pricing in 100% chance of a 25bp cut at the next BoE meeting in the end of March after yesterday’s emergency rate cut by the Fed. Incoming Governor Bailey noted the BoE can take the bank rate down to about 0.1%, but policy ammunition is "uncomfortably close" to the average rate cut needed in a cycle, stating BoE does not have a lot of room for policy manoeuvre. Bailey also noted the need to act in a co-ordinated manner with the treasury to respond to the coronavirus, and that he is optimistic on this, and has already begun meeting with chancellor Sunak on assisting small firms and that coordination with other central banks should not be ruled out, but it is not always appropriate. Elsewhere, Deputy Governor Broadbent stated there could be a role for economic policy to support activity and credit provision amid the coronavirus outbreak, highlighting the BoE is in close contact with government officials and other central banks, but he noted what matters most will be the potential medium-term impact on inflation.

* REPO: The NY Fed’s overnight repo operation was oversubscribed for a second consecutive day on Wednesday: USD 100bln accepted versus USD 111bln of bids. This comes after recent Term operations being oversubscribed too, at a time when the Fed is looking to taper its activity in the funding markets. As rates fall in the front-end, Primary Dealers (PDs) look to take further advantage of the cheap financing; some desks also note recent market vol as leaving dealers with more collateral on hand to repo too. Additionally, Treasury auction settlement is exerting further stress on the demand for cash, something which has been exhibited in recent rises in the GC rate outside of the FFR. The Fed’s party line is that it will remain in repo markets and bill purchases through the April 15th tax season, after which it would reassess; note Fed’s Bullard reiterated this on Wednesday. Further to the point, Credit Suisse’s funding market “wizard/guru” Zoltan Pozsar recently suggested that Fed rate cuts, in absence of open-ended liquidity support through its balance sheet (e.g. QE), would likely re-steepen the curve and cause further pressures on PD funding needs as money market accounts move into bonds, ergo, less cash on balance sheets available for repo.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 8 TICKS HIGHER AT 136-08. The Treasury curve bull steepened pronouncedly as the front-end rallied amid global monetary policy easing – BoC being the latest G7 to cut rates. Desks noted a slew of real money/CTAs engaging in steepeners on Wednesday, finding some momentum on the back of a strong ADP employment report (183k vs. exp. 170k) and ISM Non-Mfg. (57.3 vs. exp. 54.9), in addition to a pickup in appetite for equities. Meanwhile, as more corporate IG issuers return to the dollar market, the belly- to long-end was under additional pressure as issuance played catch up following the two-week dry spell. Although one desk noted a particular asset manager who was keeping a lid on the steepening, selling a total of 34,452 TUs (2s) while buying 11,175 TNs (10s). The overhanging virus and potential QE is likely providing some support further out the curve. By settlement, 10-year yield had risen back to 1.00%, whilst the whole curve had steepened with the 2-year yield down 8bps and the 30-year yield unchanged on the day.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +4.2% at 3130, NDX +4.1% at 8949, DJ +4.9% at 27,090. Sectors: Health +5.8%, Utilities +5.7%, Staples +4.9%, Tech +4.3%, Industrials +4%, Industrials +4.2%, Materials +4%, Real Estate +4%, Communications svs. +3.6%, Discretionary +3.4%, Financials +3.3%, Energy +2.2%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Health care (XLV), particularly insurers (UNH, CI, ANTM, CNC, HUM), outperformed today with the sector up over 5% heading into the tail end of the session as Biden staged a turnaround on Super Tuesday securing 10 state victories out of the 14 Super Tuesday primaries, resulting in a blow to Sanders who is an advocate for Medicare for all. Uber (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) benefitted after the former’s CEO stated the co. is in a better position now to achieve profitability on an EBITDA basis in Q420 than it was on the initial announcement, while also adding its Eats business is benefitting from the coronavirus. United Airlines (UAL) announced it is reducing flights and freezing hiring amid COVID-19; trimming international flying by 20% and US flying by 10% for April, with similar reductions expected for May. Skyworks (SWKS) cut its Q2 guidance due to the coronavirus impacting demand; noting the virus has not disrupted manufacturing operations to date. General Electric (GE) reaffirmed FY20 guidance, although noted FCF from its manufacturing operations in Q1 will be hit between USD 300-500mln, and an impact on negative operating profit of USD 200-300mln Impact of COVID-19 is not included in outlook beyond Q1 but it is incorporated in its FY guidance. 

*EARNINGS: Ross Stores (ROST) traded lower on poor guidance, Nordstrom (JWN) in the red after top and bottom line misses, while also adjusting its leadership structure. Dollar Tree (DLTR) hit on a revenue miss and poor FY guidance, HPE down on cautious CFO comments and mediocre earnings. Campbell Soup (CPB) surged after reporting solid earnings and an increase to its FY EPS forecast.

* M&A: Two major Metro (B4B GY) shareholders denied they had been approached by Sysco (SYY) over a potential takeover so far, rebuffing the source reports yesterday. Elsewhere, Prosiebensat Media (PSM GY) is reportedly near a deal to acquire Meet Group (MEET), according to sources. ViacomCBS (VIAC) is reportedly seeking strategic alternatives for its publishing house, Simon & Schuster, where the co. reportedly wants USD 1.2bln for the unit.

* FX WRAP: USD regained some of the post emergency rate cut losses aided by a weaker EUR and JPY while 10-year yields reclaimed the 1% figure. EUR trended lower throughout the day as cases continue to pick up in the EZ, which prompted EC to issue a technical recession warning. CAD traded flat against the buck after initially trending firmer on a slight (early) rebound on oil prices, although gains were wiped out after the BOC followed the fed by cutting 50bps while also leaving the door open for further easing. JPY undermined by the greenbacks recovery and as risk sentiment took a positive turn, which failed to benefit the precious metal which remains above the 1600 mark as it benefits from the global easing expected, diminishing real yields. AUD & NZD both firmer today as AUD benefits from better than expected growth data, whereas NZD likely benefitting on the expectation of a reasonable 25bp cut (following suit with its Antipodean counterpart), as oppose to 50bps we have seen elsewhere, although money markets are currently pricing in 38bps worth of easing at the March meeting. EMFX was mixed as BRL continues to weaken despite firmer GDP, although Services PMI data was weak. RUB weaker as oil prices decline, boding well for TRY.

analysis_details: The Treasury curve bull steepened pronouncedly as the front-end rallied amid global monetary policy easing – BoC being the latest G7 to cut rates. Desks noted a slew of real money/CTAs engaging in steepeners on Wednesday, finding some momentum on the back of a strong ADP employment report (183k vs. exp. 170k) and ISM Non-Mfg. (57.3 vs. exp. 54.9), in addition to a pickup in appetite for equities. Meanwhile, as more corporate IG issuers return to the dollar market, the belly- to long-end was under additional pressure as issuance played catch up following the two-week dry spell. Although one desk noted a particular asset manager who was keeping a lid on the steepening, selling a total of 34,452 TUs (2s) while buying 11,175 TNs (10s). The overhanging virus and potential QE is likely providing some support further out the curve. By settlement, 10-year yield had risen back to 1.00%, whilst the whole curve had steepened with the 2-year yield down 8bps and the 30-year yield unchanged on the day.

analysis_details: Energy markets reversed earlier gains on Wednesday as jitters grew on the eve of OPEC+ that Russia would not provide its support. In the earlier session, sources reports, that members were pushing for production cuts in excess of 600k BPD and even more than 1mln BPD, in addition to wider risk appetite, kept positive momentum in the crude complex. However, the OPEC optimism faced headwinds on WSJ sources reporting that Russia had been opposed to a Saudi-proposed 1.2mln BPD additional cut. Note that earlier Iranian oil minister had said that he believes Russia would resist the cuts until the last moment, something that the market generally considers Russia’s de facto strategy to OPEC meetings. The JMMC technical committee, which concluded there meeting on Wednesday, reportedly did not reach an agreement due to Russia’s reluctance for additional cuts, according to a source, which suggested Russia wants an extension of the existing cuts to the end of Q2 while other members want between 1mln-1.5mln. However, the UAE Energy Minister later said, as cited by S&P Global Platts, that the technical committee made a recommendation that Russia is onboard with, although would not provide further details. Meanwhile across the Atlantic, the latest EIA US inventory data was largely ignored, it was a bullish report however, where crude stocks built less than expected, including a chunky draw at Cushing, and both the products reported larger than expected draws, although production did rise to 13.1mln BPD with a larger decline than expected in refinery utilisation. Elsewhere, Goldman Sachs lowered its oil price forecasts in which it sees Brent to trough in April at USD 45/bbl then recover to USD 60/bbl vs. prev. forecast of decline to USD 53/bbl then recovery to USD 65/bbl

Fed Beige Book: US Economic activity expanded at a modest to moderate rate over past several weeks with COVID-19 being cited as a risk, as well as already weighing on travel and tourism
content:
• Manufacturing activity expanded in most of the US although some supply chain delays due to the virus were reported and producers feared further disruption
  • Consumer spending generally picked up although growth was uneven across the US
  • Most near-term outlooks were for modest growth with the virus and the Presidential election cited as a risk
  • Employment increased at a slight to moderate pace, constrained by tight labour market; manufacturers, retailers and transportation firms had lower demand in some districts
  • Wages rose at a modest to moderate pace, pressured higher by the tight labour market and raise in minimum wage
  • Some firms were optimistic the Phase One trade deal would cut prices of goods, although some still struggled with tariffs and feared further of COVID-19's effects on prices
  • Click here for full release

However, losses were short-lived and the over 10 minutes the E-mini was back to pre-beige book levels.

analysis_details:

  • Biggest states (delegates): California (415), Texas (228), North Carolina (110), Virginia (99), Massachusetts (91), Minnesota (75), Colorado (67), Tennessee (64), Alabama (52), Oklahoma (37), Arkansas (31), Utah (29), Maine (24), Vermont (16).

Daily FX Wrap: BoC follows the Fed, but Euro flags on escalating COVID-19 contagion
content:
CAD

Hot on the heels of the FOMC’s emergency policy move the BoC opted to cut by the same 50bp margin and the accompanying statement was more dovish/downbeat given business activity falling sharply in some regions and the disruption to supply chains evident in commodity prices and the Loonie. Moreover, the Bank expressed concern that business and consumer sentiment could deteriorate as the coronavirus spreads, and in turn weigh even more on activity. Hence, the BoC is prepared to adjust (lower) rates further if warranted. Usd/Cad touched 1.3400 in response from around 1.3340, but then breached the big figure on a second wave of buying as US non-manufacturing ISM beat consensus and added more upside impetus to the headline pair and DXY that pared more post-Fed declines to a 97.600 high (only a fraction below the 97.695 pre-intermeeting ease peak).

EUR 

Notwithstanding the Loonie’s BoC-inspired travails, the single currency is propping up the major ranks after a rise in the number of nCoV cases in Italy and France prompted the EC to issue a technical recession warning for both Eurozone member states and the former to shut down all schools and universities with plans to ban all public events, shut cinemas and theatres. Eur/Usd extended its retreat from Tuesday’s 1.1200+ highs to just below 1.1100, but is now back above the round number and 200 DMA pending the ECB’s contribution to the combat China’s outbreak and contagion cause.

JPY/CHF/GBP

All undermined by the Dollar’s broad recovery to an extent and the Yen also due to a risk revival more so than the Franc that remains mixed after more verbal SNB intervention and a dip back into deflationary y/y inflation. Indeed, Usd/Jpy rebounded through 107.00 following comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda sounding more concerned about the knock-on effects of the increasing global epidemic, while Usd/Chf held around 0.9550 and Eur/Chf remained towards the bottom of a 1.0705-1.0620 range. Meanwhile, Sterling was volatile amidst more speculation that the BoE may take a leaf out of the Fed’s book and deliver some pre-March policy gathering stimulus, with Cable straddling 1.2800 and Eur/Gbp pivoting 0.8700 (with the 100 HMA and 200 DMA capping the upside respectively, latter for the 3rd time).

AUD/NZD/NOK/SEK

The clear G10 outperformers, as the Aussie gleaned additional post-RBA traction from better than expected growth data, while the Kiwi piggy-backed on the premise that RBNZ might match its Antipodean peer with a more measured/standard ¼ point reduction of the OCR. Similarly, the Scandi Crowns appreciated against the backdrop of firmer oil prices and reports that OPEC+ may be discussing a 1+ mn bpd cut (albeit with Saudi Arabia pushing for more and against Russian resistance) another healthy looking Swedish PMI.

EM 

Some respite for most regional currencies, as the Yuan continues to welcome efforts to contain the virus in China where the pace of contamination and fatalities seems to be incrementally declining, while the Lira is also hoping for a constructive conclusion to tomorrow’s talks between Turkey and Russia about resolving differences over the Syrian border. Elsewhere, little net movement in the Zloty after the NBP stood pat and retained a steady stance.

subject: Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dovish) says rates are in the right place for now, says risks are rising that COVID-19 could be more severe; Fed has taken out some insurance
content:
• Situation is very fluid; don't prejudge and put a lot of weight on the March FOMC meeting
  • Sees downside risks and stands ready to adjust policy; all tools are on the table
  • Baseline economy is quite good
  • Rationale for emergency rate cut was that if they were going to cut at the March meeting, why not cut now
  • His base case is that the US economy will do quite well and get the virus under control - thinks we will not see as bad a virus effect as people think
  • Rate cuts could encourage investments that would not normally been made
  • Higher inflation from supply shocks would be welcome although is not expecting that
  • Fed will get through April time, regarding repo operations, and then reassess

Fixed and FX latest: bonds remain mixed and Buck on the recovery track
content: Wednesday’s big events are arguably still to come given that the BoC is overwhelmingly expected to join the ranks of global Central Banks providing some relief against China’s coronavirus, but the market unsure whether it will go 25 bp or 50 bp, while the services ISM is the next major US macro releases post-Fed and ADP. However, debt remains mixed and off best levels as Bunds slip to a new 174.63 Eurex trough in contrast to the Dollar that is clawing back more lost ground with the DXY just shy of 97.500 and a fresh post-Fed peak of 97.564. Coincidentally, a minor uptick in Usd/Cad after a retreat in Canadian labour productivity has underpinned the index amidst consolidation in other pairs.

Newsquawk Central Banks - PREVIEW: BOC policy decision (March 2020)
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

The BOC is now expected to cut rates by at least 25bps at its March meeting (4th March, 1500 GMT/1000 ET). It is a statement only affair, however, governor Poloz will deliver remarks on Thursday after the release of the Economic Progress Report. In terms of the data, we have seen some stabilisation in recent metrics - the BOC had wanted to see evidence that a growth slowdown was persistent before it cut rates. However, the narrative has shifted, amid the outbreak of the coronavirus, with major global central banks leaning dovish to cushion economies from the fallout. As such, the BOC has plenty of cover to cut rates, with some flagging risks of a deeper cut than the consensus implies.

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD, Equities Steady as Markets Digest Fed Ease
content:
•   USD mixed to firmer versus G10 peers after Fed ease, more cuts expected.
  •   CAD out-performs modestly ahead of anticipated BoC cut.
  •   EUR steady around mixed Services PMI data.
  •   GBP little changed, markets ponder scope for BoE easing.
  •   JPY under-performs as risk appetite strengthens.
  •   AUD leads G10, gains with commodity peers.
  •   MXN strengthens on broader risk mood, may retest 19.20 area.

subject: Japan confirms nine new COVID-19 cases in Osaka and first in Miyazaki prefecture, according to Kyodo
Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 4th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities saw a relatively shaky start to the session before eventually moving back into positive territory (Eurostoxx 50 +1.4%)
  • The DXY has regained some composure after Tuesday’s slide in wake of the Fed’s early or emergency March policy easing
  • WTI and Brent prices are firmer this morning with further sources reports suggesting the possibility of deeper production cuts in excess of 1mln bpd
  • Super Tuesday Update: Joe Biden is said to have won 319 delegates (372 total) so far vs. 242 delegates (302) for Bernie Sanders
  • ECB Governing Council held a conference call yesterday on COVID-19 impact and discussed operational issues but decided that a monetary policy response was not on the agenda, according to sources
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US ADP & ISM Non-Manufacturing. BoC Rate Decision, BoE’s Broadbent, Bailey & Fed’s Bullard

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

China reported 119 additional coronavirus cases and 38 additional deaths on March 3rd vs. Prev. 125 additional cases and 31 new deaths on March 2nd, to bring the total number of mainland cases to 80270 and death toll at 2871. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 809 additional coronavirus cases and 4 additional deaths to bring total cases to 5621 and death toll to 32, while Italy's total cases rose to 2502 from 2036 and death toll increased to 79 (Prev. 52) the prior day. (Newswires/Yonhap)

US VP Pence said there are 77 domestic cases of coronavirus and Washington State confirmed 3 more deaths to bring the total death toll in US to 9, while he added the task force will brief the House on Wednesday. (Newswires)

World Bank announced a USD 12bln immediate financing package to help deal with coronavirus outbreak and said there are many unknowns regarding the economic and health impact, while it also noted far more resources may be needed and that many have requested aid from the World Bank although did not name them. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian bourses traded somewhat mixed following from the weak rollover from Wall St. where all major indices slumped around 3% despite the Fed delivering an emergency rate cut of 50bps, as this failed to alleviate the slowdown concerns from the coronavirus outbreak and the G7 statement on coordinated policy action also provided little in terms of details in which it did not commit to any monetary or fiscal action. Nonetheless, US equity futures partially nursed losses overnight as focus turned to Super Tuesday Democrat Primary results which showed former VP Biden performed well although there was still far to go with the biggest states California and Texas still up for grabs. ASX 200 (-1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (U/C) were lacklustre with Australia pressured by underperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector due to virus fallout concerns and the lower interest rate environment, while the Japanese benchmark was indecisive amid a choppy currency and uncertainty regarding the Tokyo Olympics after a minister suggested the event could be held back although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later reiterated they will continue to move ahead with preparations. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) were temperamental despite speculation the PBoC could lower rates this month and after the HKMA moved in lockstep with the Fed through a 50bps rate cut, as participants also digested further weak data in which Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs printed record lows. Finally, 10yr JGBs surged above the 154.00 level as they tracked the upside in T-notes following the Fed’s emergency rate cut and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 800bln in up to 5yr JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9514 vs. Exp. 6.9503 (Prev. 6.9516)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Feb) 26.5 vs. Exp. 48.0 (Prev. 51.8); record low Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Feb) 27.5 (Prev. 51.9); record low.

HKMA lowered its base rate by 50bps to 1.50% following the Fed rate cut and Macau also lowered its discount window rate by 50bps to 1.50%. (Newswires)

China Securities Journal noted speculation the PBoC may reduce rates on open market operations this month. (Newswires)

China Global Times tweeted that China’s commitment to buy US agricultural products is unlikely to change despite the coronavirus outbreak, which has weakened domestic demand. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump commented that the market is in good shape and that he would approve a payroll tax cut for middle income earners in 2020 if the democrats supported it. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said he thought the Fed was well positioned but felt a rate cut would help boost confidence given rising risks and potential economic weakening, while he added the possibility of hitting zero rates again means Fed should use its ammunition and that the rate cut shows it is part of a team in crisis response. Evans also stated expectation is coronavirus will have short-lived imprint on US and expects a quarter or half-year of slowing growth as well as a V-shaped rebound. (Newswires)

Super Tuesday Democrat Primary: Joe Biden is said to have won 319 delegates (372 total) so far vs. 242 delegates (302) so far for Bernie Sanders, according to NY Times

-        Biden has won Alabama, Arkansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia

-        Sanders has won Colorado, Utah and Vermont and leads in California

UK/EU

ECB Governing Council held a conference call yesterday on COVID-19 impact and discussed operational issues but decided that a monetary policy response was not on the agenda, according to sources. Call was after the FOMC emergency action. (Newswires) Note, next ECB meeting is March 12th. Additionally, the ECB have postponed all non-monetary policy conferences due to the coronavirus.

French Finance Minister Le Maire says that Europe needs to be ready to use fiscal stimulus, which is stronger than monetary stimulus for boosting the economy; If the virus last for a long period of time and growth is affected then the EZ will have to increase budget spending. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor is reportedly ready to signal the end of freezes on fuel duty at next week’s budget and will reportedly levy a 3% tax on non-residents purchasing property. (FT)

A cross-party group of around 40 MPs are set to call on the government to lower Huawei’s participation in the UK’s 5G infrastructure from 35% to zero by 2023. (Telegraph)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI Final (Feb) 53.2 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3); Composite PMI Final (Feb) 53.0 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3)

EU Markit Services Final PMI (Feb) 52.6 vs. Exp. 52.8 (Prev. 52.8); Comp Final PMI (Feb) 51.6 vs. Exp. 51.6 (Prev. 51.6)

-        German Markit Services PMI (Feb) 52.5 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3); Comp Final PMI (Feb) 50.7 vs. Exp. 51.1 (Prev. 51.1)

EQUITIES

European equities saw a relatively shaky start to the session before eventually moving back into positive territory (Eurostoxx 50 +0.5%) as markets attempt to gauge the efficacy of recent and potential upcoming stimulus efforts from global authorities. Stateside, futures markets are indicating the likelihood of a positive open on Wall St., however, it remains to be seen whether this is a result of genuine optimism over recent policy responses or merely a fleeting paring back of some of yesterday’s declines. Furthermore, attention in the US will also partially be placed on the fallout from the Democratic “Super Tuesday” which saw a stellar performance for former VP Biden who now holds a total of 320 delegates (at the latest count) vs. 252 for Sanders. In terms of how this will effect the broader performance for stocks going forward, analysis is mixed. Some argue that Biden is more market-friendly than Sanders and thus his success should be seen as a positive, whereas others argue that even though Sanders would be detrimental for markets (should he enter the White House), Trump would be more likely to beat him, with Trump viewed by most as the overall most market-positive candidate. Sectoral performance in Europe is higher across the board with outperformance for material, healthcare and consumer staples. Individual movers include Eurofins Scientific (+7.8%) at the top of the Stoxx 600 post-earnings, Dialog Semiconductor (+3.6%) shares have been supported after posting favourable revenue guidance, whilst Rio Tinto (+3.6%) trade higher after a broker upgrade at SocGen. To the downside, the clear outlier is Intu Properties (-20%) after abandoning its equity placement, whilst Metro AG (-4.2%) are lower following reports of a potential tie-up with Sysco; reports that were later rebuffed.

Chinese car sales -80% YY, February prelim data, according to PCA. (Newswires)

FX

DXY - The index and Greenback in general have regained some composure after Tuesday’s slide in wake of the Fed’s early or emergency March policy easing, with the former back above the 97.000 handle within a 97.423-104 range vs yesterday’s 96.926 base. However, Usd/major and EM pairs are mostly softer after FOMC Chairman Powell refrained from signalling that the 50 bp inter-meeting rate cut would likely suffice to protect the US economy from nCoV contagion, leaving the door ajar for more stimulus if necessary.

AUD/NZD/CAD/CHF/SEK/NOK - The Aussie appears to be building a firmer base on the 0.6600 handle vs its US peer on the back of firmer than forecast Q4 GDP data that will feed the notion of no back-to-back or follow up action from the RBA after its ¼ point reduction even though Deputy Governor Debelle warns that the bushfires and coronavirus will have more of an adverse impact on the economy in Q1. This has also lifted Aud/Nzd back above 1.0500 as the Kiwi continues to trail behind awaiting the RBNZ’s response to the COVID-19 outbreak later this month, with Nzd/Usd still struggling to advance beyond 0.6300. On that note, the Loonie is deriving some traction from another rebound in crude prices ahead of the BoC, albeit not as much as the Norwegian Crown given Eur/Nok rooted towards the base of a 10.3045-3730 band, as Usd/Cad pivots 1.3350. In terms of market pricing, -25 bp is baked in, but the probability of a like-for-like Fed move is also high at around 80%, hence options assigning a wide 75 pip break-even for the event. Elsewhere, while the SNB sits tight pending its quarterly review next week, Usd/Chf is holding circa 0.9550 and hardly acknowledging Swiss CPI slipping below zero y/y again, but the Swedish Krona has gleaned support from another upbeat PMI to straddle 10.5500 vs the Euro.

GBP/EUR/JPY - All on the back foot as the Buck regroups, with Cable still unable to sustain gains above 1.2800 and respecting the 200 DMA (1.2830) amidst heightened BoE policy stimulus calls, while Eur/Usd has faded ahead of 1.1200 and hefty option expiries between 1.1200-05 in 1.6 bn as the coronavirus spreads and especially in Italy. Lastly, the Yen has pared gains around 107.00 following comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda indicating a higher level of vigilance for Chinese epidemic effects and a potentially lower bar for a policy response.

EM - Broad recoveries across the region, and with the Lira also acknowledging positive comments from Turkish President Erdogan contending that a ceasefire can be forged at Thursday’s meeting with Russia to try and resolve the ongoing stand-off in Syria.

RBA's Debelle we have the capacity to cut once more, after that will have to consider QE; does not think that negative rates are something that should be contemplated; bushfires did not have much of an impact on Q4 2020 GDP, but will have a larger impact in Q1 2020, according to his testimony to lawmakers. (Newswires)

Australian GDP (Q4) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%). Australian GDP (Q4) Y/Y 2.2% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 1.7%)

Australian Treasurer Frydenberg said working on targeted series of fiscal measures and that the Treasury will detail the estimate of virus impact on Thursday. (Newswires)

RBNZ said we are prepared to ensure a well-functioning financial system, while it is to explain principles regarding unconventional tools on March 10th but will not discuss current conditions or policy. (Newswires)

Notable Option Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1060 (1.7BLN), 1.10775 (430M), 1.1100 (940M), 1.1150 (1.5BLN), 1.1180 (470M), 1.1200-05 (1.6BLN)

-        NZD/USD: 0.6275 (510M), 0.6400 (375M), 0.6450 (561M)

-        USD/CAD: 1.3300 (1BLN), 1.3350 (710M)

FIXED

Gilts continue to edge it alongside Eurozone peripheral bonds in contrast to Bunds that have reversed all and more of their post-Fed gains to trade below parity and Tuesday’s close (-15 ticks vs +61 ticks at one stage). However, trade remains volatile and somewhat erratic as debt futures continue to eye stocks as a proxy for broad risk appetite while weighing up or attempting to second guess what the rest of the global Central Band community has in store to combat the economic fall-out from COVID-19. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are holding firm, though off best levels seen since the FOMC took bold action, as the 10 year yield sits sub-1% awaiting a busy US docket in terms of data and more pre-NFP pointers.

GEOPOLITICS 

Russia Defense Ministry said Turkey has violated international law and failed to meet its obligations by increasing troops in Idlib, while it added that attacks on its Syrian airbase have become daily. (Newswires)

Russian Defence Ministry says that Militants have attempted to use chemical weapons in Syrian, Sraqeb, according to Tass. (Tass)

Turkish President Erdogan expects a ceasefire to be achieved quickly in Syria's Idlib following discussions with Russian President Putin tomorrow. (Newswires)

Tokyo 2020 announces that measures such as limiting the number of entrants to celebration venues could be imposed. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent prices are firmer this morning, following yesterday’s emergency stimulus action by the Fed as markets are firmly on the look-out for action elsewhere, but more pertinently for the complex itself is reports pertaining to OPEC, as the JMMC meeting gets underway today. Comments this morning point towards Russia and Saudi holding bilateral discussions but reports note that Russia are likely to make their decision on cuts at the last moment. In terms of the magnitude of cuts sources point towards a cut around the 1mln mark, but that any figure above the 600k BPD initial JTC recommendation must be considered. These reports have coincided with upside in the crude complex, which saw WTI briefly surpass the USD 48/bbl mark; however, this upside has occurred alongside a general grinding higher in risk sentiment so its unclear how much of the move can be directly attributed to the OPEC commentary. Indicative scheduling for this week’s OPEC events saw the JMMC commence from around 11:00GMT today, with OPEC set to meet tomorrow before the entire OPEC+ committee convenes on Friday. As well as a decision on any additional cuts, focus will be placed on remarks around compliance as countries such as Russia are still not meeting their quota. Looking ahead, today sees the EIA weekly release, which is expected to see a build of 3.333mln barrels which, if correct, is just shy of double yesterday’s API crude build at 1.7mln. In terms of metals, it has been a relatively steady day for spot gold that is currently just shy of the USD 1650/oz mark, which appears to be capping price action and is in proximity to yesterday’s high; after the metal was supported on the emergency FOMC cut.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks +1.7mln vs. Exp. +2.6mln (Prev. +1.3mln). (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs lowered its oil price forecasts in which it sees Brent to trough in April at USD 45/bbl then recover to USD 60/bbl vs. Prev. forecast of decline to USD 53.bbl then recovery to USD 65/bbl, while Morgan Stanley cut Q2 Brent forecast to USD 55/bbl (Prev. USD 57.5/bbl) and lowered WTI forecast to USD 50/bbl (prev. USD 52.50/bbl). (Newswires)

OPEC Commentary:

-        Iranian oil minister believes that Russia will resist until the last moment before agreeing to lower output, according to Shana. Based on JTC recommendations, oil production cut should be at least 500k bpd.

-        Russian Energy Minister Novak and Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz are to hold bi-lateral talks ahead of the JMMC OPEC+ meeting, Tass. (Tass)

-        Some OPEC+ members reportedly pushing for a cut of 1.2mln BPD, according to Energy Intel analyst, citing sources. (Twitter)

subject: FX Morning Colour: Dollar pares some post-rate cut losses, but still pressured
content:
DXY

The index and Greenback in general have regained some composure after Tuesday’s slide in wake of the Fed’s early or emergency March policy easing, with the former back above the 97.000 handle within a 97.423-104 range vs yesterday’s 96.926 base. However, Usd/major and EM pairs are mostly softer after FOMC Chairman Powell refrained from signalling that the 50 bp inter-meeting rate cut would likely suffice to protect the US economy from nCoV contagion, leaving the door ajar for more stimulus if necessary.

AUD/NZD/CAD/CHF/SEK/NOK 

The Aussie appears to be building a firmer base on the 0.6600 handle vs its US peer on the back of firmer than forecast Q4 GDP data that will feed the notion of no back-to-back or follow up action from the RBA after its ¼ point reduction even though Deputy Governor Debelle warns that the bushfires and coronavirus will have more of an adverse impact on the economy in Q1. This has also lifted Aud/Nzd back above 1.0500 as the Kiwi continues to trail behind awaiting the RBNZ’s response to the COVID-19 outbreak later this month, with Nzd/Usd still struggling to advance beyond 0.6300. On that note, the Loonie is deriving some traction from another rebound in crude prices ahead of the BoC, albeit not as much as the Norwegian Crown given Eur/Nok rooted towards the base of a 10.3045-3730 band, as Usd/Cad pivots 1.3350. In terms of market pricing, -25 bp is baked in, but the probability of a like-for-like Fed move is also high at around 80%, hence options assigning a wide 75 pip break-even for the event. Elsewhere, while the SNB sits tight pending its quarterly review next week, Usd/Chf is holding circa 0.9550 and hardly acknowledging Swiss CPI slipping below zero y/y again, but the Swedish Krona has gleaned support from another upbeat PMI to straddle 10.5500 vs the Euro.

GBP/EUR/JPY 

All on the back foot as the Buck regroups, with Cable still unable to sustain gains above 1.2800 and respecting the 200 DMA (1.2830) amidst heightened BoE policy stimulus calls, while Eur/Usd has faded ahead of 1.1200 and hefty option expiries between 1.1200-05 in 1.6 bn as the coronavirus spreads and especially in Italy. Lastly, the Yen has pared gains around 107.00 following comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda indicating a higher level of vigilance for Chinese epidemic effects and a potentially lower bar for a policy response.

EM 

Broad recoveries across the region, and with the Lira also acknowledging positive comments from Turkish President Erdogan contending that a ceasefire can be forged at Thursday’s meeting with Russia to try and resolve the ongoing stand-off in Syria.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

4th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian bourses traded somewhat mixed following from the weak rollover from Wall St. where all major indices slumped around 3% despite the Fed delivering an emergency rate cut of 50bps, as this failed to alleviate the slowdown concerns from the coronavirus outbreak and the G7 statement on coordinated policy action also provided little in terms of details in which it did not commit to any monetary or fiscal action. Nonetheless, US equity futures partially nursed losses overnight as focus turned to Super Tuesday Democrat Primary results which showed former VP Biden performed well although there was still far to go with the biggest states California and Texas still up for grabs. ASX 200 (-1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were lacklustre with Australia pressured by underperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector due to virus fallout concerns and the lower interest rate environment, while the Japanese benchmark was indecisive amid a choppy currency and uncertainty regarding the Tokyo Olympics after a minister suggested the event could be held back although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later reiterated they will continue to move ahead with preparations. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were temperamental despite speculation the PBoC could lower rates this month and after the HKMA moved in lockstep with the Fed through a 50bps rate cut, as participants also digested further weak data in which Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs printed record lows. Finally, 10yr JGBs surged above the 154.00 level as they tracked the upside in T-notes following the Fed’s emergency rate cut and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 800bln in up to 5yr JGBs

4th March 2020

 

·       Asian bourses traded somewhat mixed following from the weak rollover from Wall St. where all major indices slumped around 3%

·       Participants digested further weak data in which Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs printed record lows

·       HKMA lowered its base rate by 50bps to 1.50% following the Fed rate cut and Macau also lowered its discount window rate by 50bps to 1.50%.

·       US VP Pence said there are 77 domestic cases of coronavirus, whilst Washington State confirmed 3 more deaths to bring the total death toll in US to 9

·       DXY languished after the Fed announced a 50bps emergency rate cut but with downside stemmed after it found support at the 97.00 level

·       Super Tuesday Democrat Primary results showed a good performance by Biden (241 delegates won so far) vs. Sanders (174 delegates won so far)

·       Looking ahead highlights include German Retail Sales, EZ & UK Services and Composite PMI (Final), US ADP & ISM Non-Manufacturing. BoC Rate Decision, BoE’s Broadbent & Fed’s Bullard; supply from the UK

 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

China reported 119 additional coronavirus cases and 38 additional deaths on March 3rd vs. Prev. 125 additional cases and 31 new deaths on March 2nd, to bring the total number of mainland cases to 80270 and death toll at 2871. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 516 additional coronavirus cases and 4 additional deaths to bring total cases to 5328 and death toll to 32, while Italy's total cases rose to 2502 from 2036 and death toll increased to 79 (Prev. 52) the prior day. (Newswires/Yonhap)

US VP Pence said there are 77 domestic cases of coronavirus and Washington State confirmed 3 more deaths to bring the total death toll in US to 9, while he added the task force will brief the House on Wednesday. (Newswires)

World Bank announced a USD 12bln immediate financing package to help deal with coronavirus outbreak and said there are many unknowns regarding the economic and health impact, while it also noted far more resources may be needed and that many have requested aid from the World Bank although did not name them. (Newswires) 

ASIA-PAC

Asian bourses traded somewhat mixed following from the weak rollover from Wall St. where all major indices slumped around 3% despite the Fed delivering an emergency rate cut of 50bps, as this failed to alleviate the slowdown concerns from the coronavirus outbreak and the G7 statement on coordinated policy action also provided little in terms of details in which it did not commit to any monetary or fiscal action. Nonetheless, US equity futures partially nursed losses overnight as focus turned to Super Tuesday Democrat Primary results which showed former VP Biden performed well although there was still far to go with the biggest states California and Texas still up for grabs. ASX 200 (-1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were lacklustre with Australia pressured by underperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector due to virus fallout concerns and the lower interest rate environment, while the Japanese benchmark was indecisive amid a choppy currency and uncertainty regarding the Tokyo Olympics after a minister suggested the event could be held back although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later reiterated they will continue to move ahead with preparations. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were temperamental despite speculation the PBoC could lower rates this month and after the HKMA moved in lockstep with the Fed through a 50bps rate cut, as participants also digested further weak data in which Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs printed record lows. Finally, 10yr JGBs surged above the 154.00 level as they tracked the upside in T-notes following the Fed’s emergency rate cut and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 800bln in up to 5yr JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9514 vs. Exp. 6.9503 (Prev. 6.9516)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Feb) 26.5 vs. Exp. 48.0 (Prev. 51.8); record low Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Feb) 27.5 (Prev. 51.9); record low.

HKMA lowered its base rate by 50bps to 1.50% following the Fed rate cut and Macau also lowered its discount window rate by 50bps to 1.50%. (Newswires)

China Securities Journal noted speculation the PBoC may reduce rates on open market operations this month. (Newswires)

China Global Times tweeted that China’s commitment to buy US agricultural products is unlikely to change despite the coronavirus outbreak, which has weakened domestic demand. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor is reportedly ready to signal the end of freezes on fuel duty at next week’s budget and will reportedly levy a 3% tax on non-residents purchasing property. (FT)

A cross-party group of around 40 MPs are set to call on the government to lower Huawei’s participation in the UK’s 5G infrastructure from 35% to zero by 2023. (Telegraph)

ECB’s Villeroy said the bank would stand ready to take appropriate and targeted measures if it is necessary, while he added that governments with fiscal space should use it and growth should remain positive for the Eurozone this year. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister Altmaier said Germany will secure liquidity of companies, especially SME's and will use existing instruments such as state aid in shortened hours, guarantees, liquidity aid to strengthen consumer confidence and companies. (Newswires) 

FX

DXY languished after the Fed announced a 50bps emergency rate cut but with downside stemmed after it found support at the 97.00 level and given that markets had priced in 75bps of rate cuts for the March meeting, while the comments from Fed Chair Powell did little to suggest whether a further 25bps reduction was on its way. The Fed move benefitted most of the greenback’s major counterparts in which EUR/USD tested but failed to surmount 1.1200, and GBP/USD was lifted to the 1.2800 handle where it then hit resistance around the 100-Hour Moving Average of 1.2830.  Elsewhere, USD/JPY initially slipped below 107.00 to print a 5-month low but later rebounded in tandem with the risk appetite in Tokyo, and antipodeans were choppy as the initial gains spurred by better than expected Australian GDP were partially offset by the weak Chinese PMI data.

Australian GDP (Q4) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%). Australian GDP (Q4) Y/Y 2.2% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 1.7%)

Australian Treasurer Frydenberg said working on targeted series of fiscal measures and that the Treasury will detail the estimate of virus impact on Thursday. (Newswires)

RBNZ said we are prepared to ensure a well-functioning financial system, while it is to explain principles regarding unconventional tools on March 10th but will not discuss current conditions or policy. (Newswires)

SNB's Maechler said SNB is in talks with US officials over SNB's negative interest rate policy and readiness to intervene, while she added the SNB cannot undertake measures that are contrary to current SNB monetary policy and is never under pressure but plans to discuss and potentially tweak its current assessment for moderate global economic growth at its next meeting in two weeks. Furthermore, Maechler noted that SNB's policy rests on negative rates and readiness to intervene. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities edged mild gains overnight in which WTI crude futures tested the USD 48.00/bbl level with upside supported by a slightly narrower than expected build in headline private crude inventories and following reports OPEC+ panel recommended at least a 600k bps output cut for Q2 ahead of the extraordinary meeting which begins on Thursday. Elsewhere, gold rallied following the emergency Fed rate cut but has since plateaued overnight after hitting resistance at USD 1650/oz, while copper also benefitted by the somewhat improved risk sentiment.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks +1.7mln vs. Exp. +2.6mln (Prev. +1.3mln). (Newswires)

OPEC+ panel considered a 600k-1mln BPD oil cut and recommended at least a 600k bpd production cut, according to two sources. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs lowered its oil price forecasts in which it sees Brent to trough in April at USD 45/bbl then recover to USD 60/bbl vs. Prev. forecast of decline to USD 53.bbl then recovery to USD 65/bbl, while Morgan Stanley cut Q2 Brent forecast to USD 55/bbl (Prev. USD 57.5/bbl) and lowered WTI forecast to USD 50/bbl (prev. USD 52.50/bbl). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Russia Defense Ministry said Turkey has violated international law and failed to meet its obligations by increasing troops in Idlib, while it added that attacks on its Syrian airbase have become daily. (Newswires)

US 

Yields fell across the curve by between 3-12bps at settlement, with most of the declines being seen on the front-part of the curve; the shape of the curve steepened, with 2s30s widening by 9bps. The Fed's emergency 50bps rate cut was the drove most of the price action, and in the aftermath, there were fresh records for 10s and 30s yields, with the former falling beneath 1.00% for the first time ever. There is still pricing for further rate cuts ahead, with markets implying around 30bps of further easing through the end of the year. US T-note futures (H0) settled 23+ ticks higher at 136-00.

US President Trump US President Trump said he is working with congress and expects an USD 8.5bln emergency funding bill for the coronavirus, Trump also commented that the market is in good shape and that he would approve a payroll tax cut for middle income earners in 2020 if the democrats supported it. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (voter, hawk) said she will make her future decisions on policy in a meeting by meeting basis and look at latest coronavirus information, while she does not feel under political pressure on monetary policy and expects US rates to be on an upward path once we get past the coronavirus situation. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said he thought the Fed was well positioned but felt a rate cut would help boost confidence given rising risks and potential economic weakening, while he added the possibility of hitting zero rates again means Fed should use its ammunition and that the rate cut shows it is part of a team in crisis response. Evans also stated expectation is coronavirus will have short-lived imprint on US and expects a quarter or half-year of slowing growth as well as a V-shaped rebound. (Newswires)

Super Tuesday Democrat Primary results showed a good performance by Biden (241 delegates won so far) who either won or was projected to win Alabama, Arkansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Virginia vs. Sanders (174 delegates won so far) who led in California, Colorado, Utah and Vermont, while Texas and Maine have not yet been called. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: : Asian stocks traded mixed as focus centred on Fed's emergency rate cut, weak China PMIs and Super Tuesday results
content: Asian bourses traded somewhat mixed following from the weak rollover from Wall St. where all major indices slumped around 3% despite the Fed delivering an emergency rate cut of 50bps, as this failed to alleviate the slowdown concerns from the coronavirus outbreak and the G7 statement on coordinated policy action also provided little in terms of details in which it did not commit to any monetary or fiscal action. Nonetheless, US equity futures partially nursed losses overnight as focus turned to Super Tuesday Democrat Primary results which showed market-friendly candidate and former VP Biden performed well although there was still far to go with the biggest states California and Texas still up for grabs. ASX 200 (-1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were lacklustre with Australia pressured by underperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector due to virus fallout concerns and the lower interest rate environment, while the Japanese benchmark was indecisive amid a choppy currency and uncertainty regarding the Tokyo Olympics after a minister suggested the event could be held back although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later reiterated they will continue to move ahead with preparations. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were temperamental despite speculation the PBoC could lower rates this month and after the HKMA moved in lockstep with the Fed through a 50bps rate cut, as participants also digested further weak data in which Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs printed record lows. Finally, 10yr JGBs surged above the 154.00 level as they tracked the upside in T-notes following the Fed’s emergency rate cut and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 800bln in up to 5yr JGBs.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade mixed as focus centres on Fed's emergency rate cut, weak China PMIs and Super Tuesday results
content:
Asia bourses trade mixed following from the weak rollover from Wall St. where all major indices slumped around 3% despite the Fed delivering an emergency rate cut of 50bps, as this failed to alleviate the slowdown concerns from the coronavirus outbreak and the G7 statement on coordinated policy action also provided little in terms of details in which it did not commit to any monetary or fiscal action. Nonetheless, US equity futures have nursed some of the losses overnight as focus turns to Super Tuesday Democratic Primary results which has shown the market-friendly candidate and former VP Joe Biden performing well although there is still far to go with the biggest states in terms of candidates; California and Texas still up for grabs. ASX 200 (-1.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) are lacklustre with Australia pressured by underperformance in tech and the top-weighted financials sector due to virus fallout concerns and the lower interest rate environment, while the Japanese benchmark is indecisive amid a choppy currency and uncertainty regarding the Tokyo Olympics after a minister suggested the event could be held back although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later reiterated they will continue to move ahead with preparations. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%)and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) are also temperamental despite speculation the PBoC could lower rates this month and after the HKMA moved in lockstep with the Fed through a 50bps rate cut, as participants also digest further weak data in which Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs printed record lows.

In FX markets, the DXY languishes after the Fed announced a 50bps emergency rate cut but with downside stemmed after it found support at the 97.00 level and given that markets had priced in 75bps of rate cuts for the March meeting, while the comments from Fed Chair Powell did little to suggest whether a further 25bps reduction was on its way. The Fed move benefitted most its major counterparts in which EUR/USD tested but failed to surmount resistance at 1.1200, and GBP/USD was lifted to the 1.2800 handle where it currently resides just shy of its 100-Hour Moving Average of 1.2830 which has since capped price action. Elsewhere, USD/JPY initially slipped below 107.00 to print a 5-month low but later rebounded in tandem with the risk appetite in Tokyo, and antipodeans are choppy with initial gains spurred by better than expected Australian GDP partially offset by the weak Chinese PMI data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs have surged above the 154.00 level as they track the upside in T-notes following the Fed’s emergency rate cut and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 800bln in up to 5yr JGBs.

subject: US equity futures trade with gains overnight amid early primary results in which Biden (market friendly candidate) is projected to win Virginia and North Carolina which are both in the top 4 largest states in terms of delegates for Super Tuesday
analysis_details:
• As a guide, Super Tuesday is viewed as the most important day in the Primary race in which 1357 delegates are up for grabs accounting for a third of the total delegates and which will be keenly eyed to see if any candidate builds a significant lead that would make it difficult for rivals to catch up.
  • Biggest states (delegates): California (415), Texas (228), North Carolina (110), Virginia (99), Massachusetts (91), Minnesota (75), Colorado (67), Tennessee (64), Alabama (52), Oklahoma (37), Arkansas (31), Utah (29), Maine (24), Vermont (16).
  • Biden is seen as the most market friendly outcome given his mainstream agenda and had recently received endorsements from prior moderate candidates, although some have also argued that a win by Sanders could mean an easier opponent for President Trump and a likely continuation of the political status quo.
  • Results due from 1900EST/0000GMT, while California (largest number of delegates) polls close at 2300EST/0400GMT.
